title: Beethoven or Beyonc√©
text:
‚ÄúMozart made my baby smarter.‚Äù ‚ÄúI learn better when I listen to music.‚Äù There is plenty of discourse surrounding the efficacy of music as a supportive tool for learning. Some sources argue that listening to classical music does in fact support brain function and retention of learning content, yet most young people turn to other genres such as pop, rap, or R&B while doing tasks. Do the alternative beats and inclusion of lyrics make these genres distracting when trying to learn or do they still have some facilitate learning to some degree?
When evaluating how music affect, AI came to the following conclusions:
Avoid Lyrics for Language-Based Tasks: Music with lyrics can interfere with reading comprehension or writing. Tempo Matters: Medium tempos (~60‚Äì80 bpm) tend to be most conducive to studying. Volume Is Key: Keep music at a lower volume to avoid overwhelming the brain. Know Yourself: Some people thrive with background music, while others need silence to focus. Tailor your study environment to your preferences.
I wanted an estimate of how much information could be retained when listening to differrent genres of music and if the subject changes that nunmber‚Ä¶

Overall, Classical music proved to be the best choice for retaining information, while pop, rock, and rap appear to be distracting. So next time you‚Äôre studying, consider listening to Symphony No.¬†9 instead if Drunk In Love

title: My Social Niche
text:
Gen Z‚Äôs perception of the world is largely shaped by social media. From political views to love languages, to future profession opportunities, we form opinions by engaging with other people and considering their perspectives. The authority of social media on our lives is facilitated by influencers. Especially on TikTok, people can identify an area of interest upon which to center creative content, and with the help of the TikTok algorithm, many have the potential to become popular figures with the capabilities to profit from their videos. For many, higher education has grown increasingly unattractive as a next step following high school, causing them to attempt to become influencers as their full-time career. An important part of being a successful influencer is knowing your niche. Based on supplemental information about personality and interests, I‚Äôm curious to know what type of influencer AI thinks I should be if I wanted to maximize popularity.
Here‚Äôs how the conversation went:
Me: what type of influencer content is most popular amongst TikTok viewers
Copilot:
GRWM (Get Ready With Me): Especially in beauty and fashion, these videos blend routine with personality, often using trending sounds.
Tutorials & How-Tos: Quick, digestible guides‚Äîfrom makeup to productivity hacks‚Äîare highly engaging and shareable.
Challenges & Trends: Participating in viral challenges or remixing trending formats boosts visibility and taps into TikTok‚Äôs algorithm.
POV & Storytelling: Creators use ‚ÄúPOV‚Äù formats or short skits to share relatable experiences, often with humor or emotional depth.
Lifestyle Vlogs: Day-in-the-life clips, travel diaries, and personal routines help build parasocial connections.
Edutainment: Educational content with an entertaining twist‚Äîespecially in finance, tech, and wellness‚Äîis gaining traction.
Copilot showed the same types of content to be the most profitable for newly established influencers.
Here‚Äôs the personality/content survey I answered to determing which type of influencer I should be if I chose to follow that path!


Co-pilot advised me to try drumroll Lifestyle and Edutainment Content!
Copilot found the following types of content to be most popular and profitable for those trying to become influencers and even provided some explanation as to why they tend to resonate with audiences more than other video types. I think these types of creators benefit from the public‚Äôs craving for authenticity. We are constantly faced with big brands trying to paint themselves a certain way to incentivize purchases, so when we‚Äôre faced with genuine content, we‚Äôre appreciative of the vulnerability. Copoilot concluded that if I were to enter the influencer space, I would be most likely to succeed in one of the aforementioned disciplines. Though flattered by the idea of people being that invested in my day-to-day life, I‚Äôve noticed that, recently, audiences have grown more parasocial and have even developed a sense of entitlement to being privy to the intimate details of public figures‚Äô lives. It would be cool to be an influencer, but I need my privacy, so I think I‚Äôll stick to a more practical career!

title: It‚Äôs Just TV
text:
I grew up watching reality shows like Dance Moms and Bring It! Both shows focus on a group of about 7 young girls who travel and dance competitively every week. While viewers get to watch the girls compete and grow in their craft, a large portion of each episode revolves around the drama between their competitive moms, all of whom desire that their child be the star of their studio. I enjoyed watching the drama when I was younger to the point where I would pick my favorite dancer and mom and pick sides during their arguments. However, rewatching these shows at an older age, I realize the potential damage done to each child‚Äôs psychological health as a result of growing up in such hectic, hostile environments. The general public tends to argue that, though both shows put the girls in stressful situations due to all of the travel and new choreography that they have to juggle on top of school, the girls featured on Dance Moms had worse experiences than those on Bring It! I wanted to see if AI would be able to form an opinion on the environments of each show and conclude whether or not reality TV in general could be considered a safe environment for children.



Chat GPT was able to identify differences in the structure of each show, causing one to have produce more harmful outcomes for the young cast members. For bith shows, the competitive stress that caused the children to value perfection over performance and over-bearing schedule of being featured on reality tv were primary stressors for the children on both shows. However, AI identified the coaching styles as a distinguishing factor. The coach of dance moms placed intense pressure on the girls and promoted internal competition between teammates that viewers joined in on, leading dancers less favored to be heavily scrutinized by the public. The coach of Bring it, on the other hand, promoted community through mentorship. By not dividing the team, her leadership style enticed the viewing audience to root for the team as a whole. Bring It was decided ot be an overall healthier environment compared to Dance Moms because it fostered growth rather than stifling emotional development. When asked to generalize, AI concluded that reality tv is not a safe environment for children because of the immense pressure and lack of protection against public scrutiny.

title: Which Animation Style is Trending
text:
Animation styles have evolved over the years as new technological capabilities have allowed them to do so. Innovation has enabled companies to transition from black-and-white to colored content, from 2D to 3D styles, and more. These new possibilities invite more diverse designs; however, there is often pushback against changed styles for franchises that remain active for extended periods. For example, the Shrek movies have been enjoyed by viewers across generations; however, the trailers for the most recent film revealed drastic changes in animation, which fueled critiques from fans of the classics. Is nostalgia stopping viewers from embracing new styles, or are certain types of animation inherently more appealing to viewers regardless of previous exposure to similar content? Let‚Äôs see what AI thinks about competing ideas in animation.
AI has recognized significant changes in animation styles over the past four decades, identifying components such as line work, color vibrancy, and character expressionism as distinguishing details. While 90‚Äôs animations are recognized for ‚Äúsquiggly lines and expressive character designs‚Äù made famous by groups like Klasky-Csupo, this decade‚Äôs animations are praised for ‚Äúhighly polished animation with dynamic lighting and detailed backgrounds.‚Äù


This evolution of styles diversifies content, but how do different generations feel about new animation features?

Despite each generation‚Äôs preferences, the general consensus about the shift from 90s techniques to modern animation is the following‚Ä¶

Ultimately, I sought to determine if AI could generate images that mimicked the animation styles of these two decades. Can you guess which image represents each decade?

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Whose Jeans Will KATch My EYE
text:
The months of August and September featured extensive online discourse about the promotional ad by GAP starring Katseye and the ad by American Eagle starring Sydney Sweeney. Many critiqued American Eagle‚Äôs ad being an homage to the distasteful Calvin Klein ad that starred an underage Brooke Shields in 1980. In addition to backlash for remaking an ad already deemed inappropriate, American Eagle was also condemned for using language that seemingly idealizes genetics like Sydney Sweeney‚Äôs and promotes white supremacist narratives. GAP, oppositionally cast a Global girl group that featured members from diverse backgrounds and delivered a message of fun, versatility, and acceptance. After using AI to see the performance statistics of these ads across platforms, I plan to see if AI can break down audience response to the two ads by different demographics, including age, racial group, and region. Finally, I want to see AI‚Äôs opinion of the two ads.
Here‚Äôs how the conversation went:
Me: in 3 sentences, what is your main takeaway from public discourse about Gap‚Äôs and American Eagle‚Äôs most recent jeans ads
Copilot: Public discourse around Gap and American Eagle‚Äôs 2025 jeans ads highlights a stark contrast in strategy: Gap‚Äôs ‚ÄúBetter in Denim‚Äù campaign was praised for its inclusive, dance-driven celebration featuring global girl group KATSEYE2. Meanwhile, American Eagle‚Äôs ad with Sydney Sweeney sparked controversy over its ‚Äúgood genes‚Äù pun, drawing criticism for tone-deaf messaging and perceived eugenics undertones3. The conversation underscores how authenticity and cultural sensitivity can drive positive engagement, while provocative tactics risk backlash‚Äîeven if they generate buzz.
Me: what are the total performance metrics (likes, shares, clicks to website) of each ad across platforms
Copilot provided the following

Gap‚Äôs campaign leaned into cultural resonance and inclusivity, while American Eagle‚Äôs shock-value strategy drove massive reach and customer acquisition. If you‚Äôd like, I can help visualize this comparison or track future updates.
I then prompted it to rate audience approval across different demographics.

Microsoft Copilot successfully presented me with metrics showing the cumulative success of each ad and communicated the general reactions of audience members from various demographics. These breakdowns showed the GAP ad to be unanimously preferred to American Eagle‚Äôs. Most of the social discourse I‚Äôd seen criticized the discriminatory undertones of the American Eagle ad, so I wasn‚Äôt surprised to see this reflected in the ratings. I agree with AI‚Äôs conclusion that GAP‚Äôs inclusive casting and modernization of an old song made it resonate with such a broad audience and was the key to their success. If other brands want to see similar trends, they would benefit from following Gap‚Äôs example; however, I wonder if audiences would perceive it as a shift towards a more inclusive culture or an inauthentic, desperate cash-grab attempt.

title: Fix My Skin
text:
Skincare remains a trending topic on social media, sparking critique from people of diverse backgrounds. Its popularity has enabled thousands of people to build their own brands by sharing their go-to products and doing brand reviews with company sponsorships. We constantly see public figures deploying new skincare lines, despite there already being a multitude of functional products on the market, yet their products still sell due to their status. I‚Äôm curious about how people choose to craft their skincare routines: do they value consistency and predictability, or novelty? I prompted AI to decide what factors most people tend to consider when developing their skin routine, how those considerations change based on age group, and provide a recommendation for my skincare routine based on the products I‚Äôm currently using.
Here‚Äôs how the conversation went:
Me: In two sentences, how do you think social media has influenced people‚Äôs skincare practices
Copilot: Social media has amplified skincare trends and product recommendations, often driven by influencers and viral content, making routines more accessible but also more commercialized. It‚Äôs also fostered greater awareness of ingredients and skin conditions, encouraging people to research and personalize their skincare choices.
Me: when consumers are choosing products what do you think they pay attention to the most:consistency and predictability, or novelty
Copilot: It depends on the context‚Äîconsumers tend to value consistency and predictability when it comes to essentials like skincare, food, or household items, where reliability and trust matter most. But when shopping for fashion, tech, or entertainment, novelty often wins, driven by curiosity, trends, and the desire for something fresh or exciting.
I then prompted copilot to provide an estimate of how much weight each characteristic carries when consumers are purchasing skincare products. AI responded with the following chart:

Out of curiosity, I wanted to see what products AI would recommend for my routine based on current trends and the following supplemental information:

AI recognizes social media‚Äôs influence on how people perceive skincare and even acknowledges the risk of being misled due to the commercialization of sponsored products. Though audiences require greater awareness of potential false advertisements, social media has enabled the public to grow more aware of what they‚Äôre putting on their skin while also fostering a sense of unity/community amongst those who have become insecure due to their skin. The majority of people self-treat skin-related issues rather than seeking professional help, and when deciding what to use, AI finds that though the majority of the population values consistency & predictability, Gen Z finds novelty and innovation slightly more favorable. AI was also able to provide me with a custom skincare routine to address some of my problem areas, and like the rest of my generation, I might take its advice.

title: Love Languages
text:
In the dating circuit, whether you‚Äôre talking in person, through Tinder, or miming through a window, the conversation almost always turns to the question: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your love language?‚Äù People then decide whether their favorite way to give or receive love is through words of affirmation, physical touch, quality time, gift-giving, or acts of service. As of now, the answer to this question serves primarily as a fun fact or a guide to one‚Äôs partner for how to show interest, but I‚Äôm curious to know whether people‚Äôs love languages indicate combatibility. Are two people with the same love language most compatible or is there a combination of different languages that make a relationship more likely to succeed long-term? Let‚Äôs see what AI has to say!

what are the pros and cons of love languages

What‚Äôs good about love languages: * Improves communication: It helps people articulate their needs and understand their partner‚Äôs.

Reduces misunderstandings: Sometimes partners show love differently, so recognizing differing styles can ease friction.
Promotes empathy: It shifts the focus from how you want to give love to how the other person receives it.

The caveats:

It‚Äôs not scientific: While based on observation, love languages haven‚Äôt been rigorously supported by psychological research. They‚Äôre more of a tool than a truth.
People are dynamic: Your love language can change over time, or vary by context (e.g., romantic vs.¬†platonic relationships).
Relationships need more: Love languages aren‚Äôt a fix-all. They don‚Äôt replace boundaries, trust, or emotional maturity.


It seems AI thinks of love languages as a solid starting point for understanding a partner, but warns that they can be used as a crutch when trying to understand conflicts in a relationship.


are there any love language combinations that are more compatible than others?


Quality Time + Quality Time
  Why it works: Both partners feel loved through shared presence and undivided attention.
Natural synergy: They‚Äôre likely to spend meaningful time together, communicate well, and build emotional intimacy just by being with each other.
Acts of Service + Acts of Service
Why it works: Both express love by doing ‚Äî helping, fixing, showing up.
Natural synergy: They tend to notice and appreciate effort-based gestures. There‚Äôs a mutual understanding that love is action, not just words.
Words of Affirmation + Physical Touch
  Why it works: These two are highly expressive ‚Äî one verbally, the other physically ‚Äî and often reinforce each other.


which combinations are the least compatible?


Words of Affirmation + Acts of Service
  Why it‚Äôs tough: One person is waiting to hear love, while the other thinks they‚Äôve already shown it.
Common problem: ‚ÄúWhy do I need to say it if I do it?‚Äù vs.¬†‚ÄúWhy do you do things for me but never tell me how you feel?‚Äù
Receiving Gifts + Physical Touch
  Why it‚Äôs tough: One thrives on symbolic tokens, the other on presence and contact.
Disconnect risk: The gift-oriented partner might feel shallow to the touch-oriented one, and vice versa ‚Äî unless they learn to value each other‚Äôs gestures.
Quality Time + Acts of Service
  Why it‚Äôs tough: One partner might be busy doing things for the other (cleaning, errands), but not spending time with them ‚Äî which leads to feeling unappreciated.
Mismatch dynamic: ‚ÄúI did all this for you!‚Äù vs.¬†‚ÄúI just wanted you to sit with me.‚Äù


There‚Äôs emphasis on the fact that a mismatched pair of love languages is not doomed; they require more conscious effort to succeed.

When approaching reationships, I consider love languages as an interesting quality and something to consider when thinking about how to show care towards a person, and I was surprised to learned from AI that many people use it as a crucial factor for determining compatibility. While having the same love language would certainly be helpful, there are other factors such as emotional availability and long-term goals, that are vital to developing a healthy, sustainable relationship.

title: What‚Äôs My Zodiac
text:
Growing up, my friends and I would take Buzzfeed quizzes to see which TV characters we were most like, which aesthetic fits us, what our personality types were, etc. These quizzes always set questions that used facts like our favorite foods and musical artists to produce an answer, but now that AI can come up with new introspective questions on the spot, I thought it would be fun if, using my answers to questions it comes up with, AI would be able to accurately guess my zodiac sign. I gave 2 different platforms the same prompt to see what kind of questions I got. Though the zodiac sign is a fun, light-hearted concept to test, some people use AI to figure out potential career paths and to make big decisions, so seeing the type of questions AI asks provides insight into how it uses context to respond to users.






The systems produced different questions, but both asked about problem-solving style, how I respond to conflict, and other questions about how I conduct myself in my daily life to guess my Zodiac sign. Neither guessed correctly, but when I revealed my sign, both provided reasoning as to why my answers at least partially reflect what‚Äôs expected for the sign while also identifying deviations and explaining how a different answer to 1 question would have changed their conclusion. Both systems expanded on the reasoning and logic behind their guesses, unlike Buzzfeed quizzes. There is little need for Buzzfeed to provide reasoning for their results since the platform is used mainly by children, AI is often used for high stakes decision-making, thus users having insight into how responses are crafted are important for choosing whether or not to act on AI‚Äôs recommendations.

title: Battle of the Myths
text:
AI allows us to bring even our most fantastical ideas to life through generative imagery. Greek mythology tells stories of fierce battles between heroic demigods and mythological creatures. While we can picture some of the classics (centaur, cyclops, hydra), I‚Äôm curious to know what other mutated, hybrid creatures AI can help us to envision. Which combinations would prove to be strong competitors, and which hybrids would be less intimidating than we might think? Lastly, how would these creatures pair up against each other? Let‚Äôs have AI take us through a hypothetical knockout competition!
What random animal hybrids can AI come up with by combining 1 of Earth‚Äôs fiercest creatures and one of the most docile?

üêòü¶õ 1. Slothopotamus: Sloth + Hippopotamus = A slow-moving river guardian with mossy fur and a deceptively calm demeanor. Peaceful until provoked‚Äîthen it charges like a tank.
ü¶éüê∞ 2. Komobunny: Komodo Dragon + Rabbit = A stealthy burrower with venomous charm. It hops innocently but can unleash a toxic bite when threatened.
üêúüê¢ 3. Fire Turtle: Fire Ant + Turtle = A shell-armored swarm commander. Normally serene, but when disturbed, it unleashes coordinated attacks from beneath its shell.
üêÉü¶• 4. Buffasloth: Cape Buffalo + Sloth = A jungle wallflower with hidden rage. Moves slowly through trees but can stampede with terrifying force if cornered.
üêòü¶´ 5. Elebeaver: Elephant + Beaver = A gentle ecosystem engineer with tusks. Builds dams with precision, but defends its territory with thunderous might.
ü¶çü¶¶ 6. Ottrilla: Gorilla + Otter = A playful river brute. Loves floating on its back and cracking shells‚Äîbut has the strength to uproot trees if angered.
ü¶°üêë 7. Weesheep: Least Weasel + Sheep = A deceptively cuddly predator. Looks like a wooly puffball, but defends its flock with lightning-fast strikes.
üêºü¶à 8. Pandark: Panda + Shark = A bamboo-loving ocean lurker. Peaceful on land, but underwater it‚Äôs a silent hunter with a taste for fish and flair.

Out of these contenders, I think the Elebeaver will prove to be the fiercest competitor.
Let‚Äôs see the matches AI generates!

Looks like my top pick was knocked out in the first round :(

can you tell me the storyline of this torunament

Quarterfinals:
Komobunny outpaces and poisons the slow-moving Slothopotamus.
Fire Turtle uses swarm tactics and shell defense to outmaneuver Buffasloth.
Ottrilla outsmarts Elebeaver with agility and strength.
Pandark dominates Weesheep with stealth and aquatic power.
Semifinals:
Fire Turtle overwhelms Komobunny with coordinated defense and strategic attacks.
Pandark defeats Ottrilla using dual-terrain advantage and silent strikes.
Finals:
Pandark claims victory over Fire Turtle‚Äîits size, stealth, and versatility proving unbeatable.
It was interesting to see the storylines that AI created for each battle between these fictional creatures. I personally would have expected the Ottrilla (Otter + Gorilla hybrid) to be the victor, but I‚Äôm sure it put up a good fight!
Give it up for the winner!

title: Wait‚Ä¶ Am I Talking to AI
text:
I recently had a friend tell me about her boyfriend‚Äôs startup that is working to create an AI system that can match a user‚Äôs texting style through voice typing. While most phones already come with a voice typing feature, they are programmed to always type in American English; however, most people text using shorthand, slang, and capitalization for emphasis, which voice typing does not currently recognize. They aim to program AI so that it can recognize those patterns in a person‚Äôs typing patterns, so that when they use voice messaging, it will produce messages that match that person‚Äôs texting style. This piqued my interest in AI‚Äôs current ability to recognize and match texting patterns. I therefore provided AI with screenshots of some of my text conversations to see if AI could respond to a prompt using the same logic and communication style as the person I was texting.

I was surprised to see that the AI would not attempt to mimic the style. I found the language most interesting: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm uncomfortable‚Ä¶This could feel like I‚Äôm impersonating‚Ä¶‚Äù. The response has a level of sentience that makes AI seem also personable rather than an objective mechanical program. With all of the conversation about the ethical implications of AI, it‚Äôs ironic that AI‚Äôs response to this prompt communicates ethical misalignment with the request, despite being successful at recognizing the logic and communication patterns and declaring itself capable of imitating them when prompted.

title: Apple or Samsung
text:
The smart technology war has featured Apple and Samsung for decades, with many consumers remaining loyal to one brand despite additional capabilities that the alternative may offer. The announcement of new features incentivizes the competition to find new ideas that will capture the audience‚Äôs attention, and their efforts are often successful. After all, we‚Äôre on the 17th iPhone. The recent launch of the iPhone 17 has once again sparked conversation on social media, with many saying that Apple is running out of ideas and that this may be the push they needed to switch over to Samsung. This prompts the question, what features are truly important to consumers when choosing a technology company? Do standards and capabilities matter more in different regions? Which brand would different LLMs decree to be better, and what characteristics are these choices based on?
I asked two LLMs to choose 5 important features that consumers should consider when purchasing a smartphone and to rate Apple and Samsung‚Äôs performances in each area on a scale from 1-10.


It was interesting to see that they chose the same criteria, and that both identified Apple as the better option despite rating the individual qualities differently.
Let‚Äôs look if each brand‚Äôs market share across regions aligns with AI‚Äôs rankings.



Although Apple is significantly more popular in North America, Samsung still holds the larger global share.
After ranking the operational capabilities of each brand‚Äôs smartphone, and evaluating the adoption of their products among diverse populations, AI recognizes Apple‚Äôs technology as superior.
